review_title: Leave your ethics at the door
job_title: Faculty Member in San Francisco, CA
pros: Located in San Francisco, California
cons: When my supervisor told me I couldn’t enforce the Honor Code for a particular student I appealed to our Dean, who chastised me for disobeying my supervisor. The two of them spent the rest of the year trying to force me to resign. My supervisor changed their hours to avoid me. I was given a contract revision to sign. When I refused, I was informed it was in effect anyway. During the summer (10 month contract year) the dean demanded an in-person meeting. I made myself available by phone, and was told I would be terminated immediately if I didn’t appear in person. Students encouraged to feel that faculty are there to serve them, not promote learning. They believe their tuition buys them this right, and does not permit faculty to require quality academic work.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in San Francisco, CA
pros: USF pays well (compared to other universities) and is a nice environment in which to work. The students have become more diverse in terms of socio-economic background, ethnicity, first-gen. college students over the years, which makes the classes more interesting. They have a beautiful ideology (mission).
cons: Like most anywhere, adjuncts are the invisible cogs that make the machine run. There is resistance to giving adjuncts a seat at the table in terms of governance, and the relationship between management and the multiple unions on campus has become much more tense in the past 5 or more years. While the mission is inspiring, management figures out ways to not live the mission all the time.

job_title: Program Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Other staff members are extremely helpful and there is a good sense of inter-department community (depending on which division you work in). The benefits are good, there's tuition remission, high percentage in the 401K, and decent vacation accrual amount. It can be an okay place to work to gain some skills, make a living, and network.
cons: The hierarchy between faculty and staff can be demeaning. Staff are viewed as less than because faculty bring in the money by teaching students, and students are the money. The social justice theme is an illusion. The COVID response was to furlough and layoff crucial employees and hand all of the responsibilities to the remaining staff. Staff are stretched thin and are not treated with respect. HR accommodations will only consider physical disabilities or injuries for more flexibility in remote work during a global pandemic. Anything that is not tangible like mental health is not something HR would consider for work accommodations.

job_title: Residence Director in San Francisco, CA

job_title: IT & AV Assistant (Part Time) in San Francisco, CA

review_title: Excellent culture, but could stand an injection of "corporatism"
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
If work/ life balance is a key concern for you, this is the best place to work, hands-down.
The benefits, vaca, sick time, severance... everything is great.
The company truly believes in the values it espouses.
cons:
Usual higher-ed issues:
1) faculty have too much control over things which don't concern or affect them
2) not at all 'corporate' (e.g. don't expect "industry best practice" to beat out "my way of doing things" in how something operates)
3) incredibly resistant to change (expect to be about 5-10 years behind the industry trends)
4) Salary is *way* below standard for the same work elsewhere in SF, in any position

review_title: Great mission, struggling vision and execution
job_title: Program Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Solid non-vacation benefits in terms of health/gym, wonderful social justice mission, beautiful campus environments. Extremely diverse community, both in terms of student body and workplace.
cons: Leadership lacking vision for institution, very slow-moving, top-heavy, resistant to change. While we emphasize the social justice mission to our students, leadership fails to implement those values culturally.

job_title: Student Sports Coach in San Francisco, CA
pros: Paying students are keen , nice . helpful  but  not all the student employees care at all . Management pushes this attitude down the chain very well.  management ( especially the top of the Keret barely even comes in when there is not a tennis match or a free trip to germany possible for sports coaches HR is very unprofessional especially when it comes to discrimination use to gender or sexual preference.
cons: Bad attitude all the way down from upper management . You ignore suggestions and all you want to do is spend money on  bright new posts and think your always dealing with a bad football team player where is you shout your orders it will work. Really you both went to "sports Management" in USF Grad school . Shame on you USF for allowing these former students and long time directors to continually fire anyone who stands in their way.  If you won't play their posts ( Rugby or Judo ) don't even try to start a club up !

job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Working with small teams 
5PM means you're done with work, not expected to put in time after hours
Catholic holidays off, significant paid winter vacation 
Tuition remission if you can stick it out for that long
cons: This is an old school institution. There's little room for growth and management hires from the outside rather than promoting from within. This can be demoralizing to staff. The pay is sub par and most employees can't afford to live in San Francisco. While it's not surprising that a university isn't a progressive workplace, there's almost no opportunity for change or advancement. The university also fails to utilize tech advances that could really help the institution. One word: static.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Love love love the psych department! The professors are AMAZING and the opportunities in the SF are incredible. Coming here has been one of the best decisions I've made so far.
cons: The biggest strength that the school has is that it is smack dab in the middle of the city, but it's also it's greatest downfall. Sometimes it's hard to feel like you're on a "college campus" when the school is so integrated in the city. So if you're looking for a sterotypical college environment and large greek life I would think a bit more about coming here. Make sure USF is really what you want.

review_title: Good employer- Could be so much better
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Job Security (USF= You Stay Forever)
No need to work overtime, weekends or holidays- very flexible work arrangements
Very 'Pro-Family' and supportive of employee's personal / family lives.
cons:
Too many people are retained for too long, beyond their ability or interest to make concerted efforts at improving themselves or the University community as a whole.

Leadership weaknesses, failure to innovate, content with 'good enough' rather than becoming better. Contradictor-y values spoken, but rarely lived as example to rest of community.

review_title: Great Benefits and Stable Work Environment
job_title: Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Some may say USF stands for U Stay Forever, but there are good reasons. The benefits package are competitive especially when it comes to retirement. There is good work-life balance and the environment is very stable. Plus, you get the opportunity to help and "Change The World From Here" (University tagline), which falls in line with the mission, core value, and social justice focus of USF.
cons:
Advancement opportunities may be limited but not impossible. One may need to change divisions in order to move up since higher-ups don't tend to leave or retire.
Compensation is probably competitive in non-profit but can't compete with for-profit organizations. Finally, cost of living is sky rocketing in the San Francisco Bay Area and it wont' be cheap o live in San Francisco.

review_title: Good depending on where you work
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-Location, location, location
-Mission-based university with a thriving Jesuit spirit
-Amazing benefits, like seriously
-Lots of resources for staff
cons:
-Not much room for growth
-Like most universities, change can be slow moving in their tight lock, bureaucratic system 
-On that note, many staff work there FOREVER which usually means old school and backwards management styles and ways of operating
-HR is not supportive of low level employees just high level supervisors. Don't expect any action when reporting incidents to HR staff. 
-You'll be paid under market

job_title: Fundraiser in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-flexible schedule, you get to choose the days of the week you want to work at the beginning of each semester
-great management
-rewarding experience
-opportunity to get bonuses
-cool coworkers

-free candy
-healthy competition

cons:

review_title: Decent place to work, great benefits
job_title: Program Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-lots of opportunity for professional development
-supervisors communicate regularly and are supportive and flexible
-great central location to bus lines
-friendly and laid back office environment
-great opportunity for growth if you step up and take initiative
cons:
-if you are a hard worker, it can be demoralizing to see other program assistants slacking off while you are busting your butt (and nothing happens to them).
-hard to move up within your own department because of the Union. but you can move to another department and be promoted that way.

review_title: Front Desk Worker at Loyola Village Residence Community
job_title: Residence Hall Front Desk Clerk in San Francisco, CA
pros: It was a great experience. The desk and resident managers were very easy to work with and allowed you to be as flexible with your schedule as you needed. Plus, if you work the overnight shifts you get paid a bit more and it's usually quiet enough to get all of your homework done.
cons: Not many cons. The desk space was a little cramped but I never had issues. The only minor issue is if the next person didn't show up on time, especially during a late shift, but beyond that I enjoyed the experience.

job_title: IT Student Worker in San Francisco, CA
pros:
I love my student worker job! I think most students in my department do, as well. It is
-laid back
-friendly work environment
-encouraging (someone is always willing to help you if you're confused!)
-flexible in regards to time off
-not too stressful (which is good because students don't need additional stress)
-good experience
-love the people in this department

In regards to benefits, I believe student workers can accumulate sick hours and  *some* help with health costs according to how many hours they've worked.
cons: For student workers, pay obviously starts at minimum wage, but that said, it is a very enjoyable job and causes minimal stress. Unfortunately, pay hardly makes a dent in the amount paid to attend the schol, but I suppose that is expected.

job_title: Research Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Amazing mentors available, if you know the right people.  Flexible hours, relaxed work environment.  I had a lot of fun researching here, and learned a lot as well.
cons: Some of the labs that are ran at the University of San Francisco may seem to be not as tightly controlled as labs in other Universities, such as UCSF.  It seemed to me that it was less professional than other research lab settings.

job_title: Associate Director in San Francisco, CA
pros: The people that work at USF are mostly really great. Depending on the position, of course, you tend to get lots of autonomy and are expected to work hard but it is usually not very stressful and people are supportive and fun. Benefits are great - medical, retirement, education. They tend to promote from within. Lots of people stay for many years.
cons: There are some politics at play as you go up. Pay is not going to match corporate but it is still pretty good.

review_title: meaningful work, beautiful grounds, diverse students, and collaborative colleagues!
job_title: Academic Advisor in San Francisco, CA
pros: Campus Diversity, Excellent Benefits, Beautiful Location, Collaborative Colleagues, Good Compensation, Inspiring leadership, Strong Jesuit Values, Quality Education - focus on Service Learning, Entrepreneurship, Globalization
cons: Hard to Leave!  Also, would be nice to have more flexible work hour options, sabbatical options for staff, or mass career customization like Deloitte & Touche ...but there are some opportunities to for voluntary reduction in time for some positions.  Also, we used to get a full week of holidays between Christmas and New Year's, but that has been reduced.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: USF is a fantastic place to work! It's a small, private, liberal arts university in the heart of San Francisco that's dedicated to social justice. When you work here, everyone knows you because the number of staff people is relatively small. You really have a chance to make an impact.
cons: The usual university politics still exist..faculty vs staff challenges, etc. The  biggest issue is we are not a household name. We are always working hard to  get students to come here because everyone confuses us with UCSF or San Francisco State.

review_title: Social Justice Mission, but 'Peter Principle' in Action
job_title: Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: A culture that values education (obviously), and personal career growth. Managers understand that USF is a stop-over for bigger things, so the culture there is that most people are there to simply better themselves (like via Tuition Remission) and then move on to greener pastures.
cons: There's a cohort of people who are lifers. They began as students, or began their career early in their careers only to rise up to their level of incompetence in managerial or director roles. I'd estimate 90% of the directors are there not because of skills or merit, but because they've outlasted everyone or had another "lifer" friend help them get hired (cronyism and nepotism).

review_title: Feeling of instability throughout the school
job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: Flexible schedule. beautiful landscaping.  lots of opportunity for exercise
cons:
Culture is not welcoming. Many of the tenured employees are indifferent. The joke is that USF mean U Stay Forever. Many people have been here for over 10 years. I have been here for 1 year and feel very much like an outsider.  Departments operate in silos, not much collaboration. Strategic planning is not a strength.  Programs are started and dropped before they can really be established. 
Hilltop is beautiful but poses space challenges.

review_title: A Great Place To Get Valuable Experience
job_title: Program Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros:
- Lots of things to learn about running organizations, fundraising, strategies, events, interactions with people and all kinds of interesting interactions
- Lots of experienced professors and staff who have real-world backgrounds in various disciplines 
- Descent benefits and salaries 
- Great location (although with the great location comes TERRIBLE parking)
cons:
- Highly, HIGHLY bureaucratic and hierarchical with limited opportunities to move up the ladder
- Limited direct communication. Sometimes, its about mind-games, guessing, and finding out about information through gossip

job_title: Graduate Student in San Francisco, CA
pros: The people are incredibly friendly, and all of the people I dealt with were always happy to collaborate or lend help.
cons: The university is private, and as such, they place a huge emphasis on fundraising and high tuition.  As a graduate student, tuition is covered, but you are expected to TA every semester for a pittance of a stipend.  It is not possible to survive on this alone.  Loans or independent wealth are required.

review_title: It's not good once you see what is behind the curtain...
job_title: in Clayton, CA
pros: Great benefits, some nice people.  Great if you are with the Union.
cons: Beware of giving up your union status if you get promoted to exempt, because they will show you the true USF and you'll realize it has a lot of politics, and a lot of archaic practices that they have no interest in improving.

review_title: USF invests in you as a person
job_title: Web Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Personal growth mentoring, amazing location, safe and comfortable work environment
cons: Sometimes, there is some bureaucracy challenges and people can get caught up in titles and processes

job_title: Adjunct Lecturer in San Francisco, CA
pros: Professors are deeply committed to good teaching. A good mix of first generation college students and students with strong previous academic backgrounds makes for classes where students are disciplined about their work and thoughtful while not being too removed from broader worlds around.
cons: Administration too focused on cost-cutting small line items for a university this size that have a strong impact on staff morale and teaching quality (like support for the university centers on teaching and research excellence respectively).

job_title: Assistant Director in San Francisco, CA
pros: Wonderful benefits and opportunities to meet great people who believe in the mission of the university and are not bothered by the horrible salaries.
cons: Way too bureaucratic. Management team has been there for years and years and basically runs the place, often to the detriment of the institution.  Employee perks are slowly being taken away which, in the past, always made the terrible salaries bearable. Departmental politics and cliques create low morale, especially amongst employees who just want to do their work and not get involved with politics. University panders to international students (especially Chinese), many of whom come from wealthy families; a majority of these students really don't want to learn anything but finance so they can 'make lots of money' (direct quotes), and the only reason they're at USF is because it's easy to get into if you have lots of money, and  they really only want the degree/diploma. Very difficult for instructors who put their hearts and souls into lesson plans when students don't care and/or cheat on tests and homework just to get through the course. Rumor is that international students 'pay' for their grades. So much wasteful spending on projects that are not compatible to environment or need, eg., USF's new logo, which looks like Walmart's logo, and which replaced the former, elegant logo of many years. Thousands were spent upgrading everything to reflect the new logo which, I repeat, is cheesy at best.  This is a university that claims to change the world from there, with a focus on social justice. That is just laughable, considering it has contracts  with Coca Cola (great signing bonus for USF), that also sells Dasani bottled water, the source for which is in India and has been accused of depleting many of its clean water sources.  I used to love and support USF - l have been an employee for many years, and have double degrees from the university, as does my son and daughter-in-law - but I'm just sad that USF is slowly losing its collegial atmosphere and is becoming more like a corporation than an institution of higher learning.

review_title: Congenial atmosphere, efficient and well-funded, creative and forward-thinking workplace with great leadership
job_title: Assistant Professor in San Francisco, CA
pros: Really nice coworkers and talented staff.  President Privett is truly a great person as well as an inspiring and thoughtful orator.  Nice campus and good infrastructure.
cons: A bit too much money spent on posh events and campus beautification at the expense of the students.  A better implementation and support for professors in breaches of academic honesty.  Some students seemed a bit entitled or unmotivated, with an attitude of "just get through this".

review_title: Great people, mission-driven, overall a good place to work
job_title: Assistant Director in San Francisco, CA
pros:
- People are excellent!
- Mission-driven 
- Jesuit values are present in all parts of the University 
- Strong focus on well-being and holistic care of staff & students
cons:
- Change can be glacial or fast (fast when it's coming top down, slow when trying to change what's above) 
- Financial well-being is almost 100% dependent on enrollment, which can make for unstable FY budgets 
- Leadership at the cabinet level is disconnected from the reality of the student experience at times

review_title: Union Position, Tough Mobility, Great Work Environment
job_title: Program Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Program Assistant positions are protected by a union, which means great support and backing if needed. The work environment is great on the student affairs side and colleagues are supportive and caring. Some tuition remission available.
cons: Pay is hourly which can be touch depending on the pay period cycle (days in the month). There is limited mobility since this is a union position and could be stuck at the program assistant level if there is no motivation to move up or out. USF is often joked as "u stay forever".

review_title: Good university in a good city
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Pros: the university values, the location (especially if you are a business student), class size, network of students
cons: Students like to complain about the university which puts a damper on the general attitude of the place. It is the type of place that makes you take advantage of what you are presented with because you don't get handed anything for free (recruiting for jobs), which a lot of the entitled students can't wrap their heads around.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in San Francisco, CA
pros: If you reach the preferred hiring pool status as an adjunct, you are given life and health insurance and retirement benefits. USF has a robust union that protects part timers. There is little oversight in my department, the wages are great, and one gets a great deal of freedom to develop each course.
cons: It's a bit lonely. And, as is typical, adjuncts are treated like second class citizens. Many departments do not even have offices for their adjuncts to meet students in.

review_title: USF is one of the best employers in the nonprofit space
job_title: Program Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Pays relatively well, great health and dental benefits, USF contributes 10% of salary to a retirement account, free access to gym, awesome workplace culture, positive environment, employees are generally treated well. Most employees are unionized.
cons: Pay increases for staff and adjunct faculty are not keeping up with the cost of living increases. Morale in the workplace seems to be in slight decline.

review_title: Bosses don't know what they're doing
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: USF can be a great place. Excellent benefits. The pay is middle of the road for higher ed. There's a lot of support from faculty and staff for the university's social justice mission.
cons: Some departments have vice presidents and directors with no experience in the field. Best practices are unheard of and not adhered to. You can't learn anything new from them. They got to where they are because of who they know at the university rather than what they know. So you job becomes navigating the politics.

review_title: Tennis Coach At USF Tennis Camp
job_title: Tennis Coach in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great pay, Peter Bartlett is an amazing boss. If you are a competitive tennis player and don't mind working with kids, I strongly suggest looking into this job
cons: I live right by USF but Peter had me working most of the time at the San Francisco State location which was kind of a hassle since I do not drive. If you really have a major reason to only be able to work at one of them, tell Peter he will probably help you out

review_title: You're learning from humans, not professors.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: They have some tough standards for CS.  You have a lot of great standards and practices ingrained into your soul when you graduate
cons: The professors are professionals, meaning they have no educator background.  This can be tough.  They can be unavailable, passive-aggressive, and unrealistic.

review_title: Little to no professional growth for Program Assistants
job_title: Program Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: The Jesuit Mission is at the heart of USF.
cons: Program Assistant positions are meant to keep these individuals in these positions. While the union can be supportive when you need their assistance, being a union member can be extremely limiting. Many departments are required to keep a certain quota of program assistant positions as mandated by the union. With limited budget constraints and cuts, there's little to no room for growth for program assistants.

review_title: Good people, good paying on campus jobs for enrolled students
job_title: Annual Giving Student Caller in San Francisco, CA
pros: Worked with a great team and everyone was very supportive and friendly. Awesome work life balance, fits in perfectly with a students schedule
cons: Work becomes routine quickly and many of the people you are calling aren't interested in hearing from the school and/or donating. The calling software is in bad need of a overhall, i.e. issues with credit card payments, freezing up, ect.

review_title: I love coming to work every day and hope to work here for a very long time!
job_title: Academic Advisor in San Francisco, CA
pros: Mission-driven, Collaborative co-workers, Good Pay and Benefits, ability to take classes, students are great to work with, social justice-oriented, diverse.
cons: Small raises, not as much infertility coverage as I'd like in the health plan, hard to leave once you're here.

review_title: There are better options for work.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: This University seeks to tie the courses and degrees to the social justice mission. The campus is located centrally in SF and is well maintained.
cons: The senior administration is shady and self-serving. Often decisions made from the top-down do not reflect the best interests of the programs or students. The systems they use are archaic and extremely slow to change - I can't even imagine they would catch up. Career advancement opportunities are not clear and seems to be backdoor deals.

job_title: Student Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Working at USF as a student was an enriching experience. The hours worked well with my schedule, which made it easy for managing class and work. ItEasy access to management. Very good about scheduling around class.
cons: Very little to dislike about working at USF. One thing, there's not much food around campus unless you take a bus. On campus there are few options, just none that are that healthy. The sandwich and salad bars close early, even though they always get long lines.

job_title: Gym Staff in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good bosses, ethical, community driven and I think that they really try to consider their student staff which is nice. They help condition us professionally but still understand that school can be conflicting so they make it easy to get shifts covered if you have exams or get sick
cons: Sometimes people come in from the community who are not students or staff and are very nice and other times they come in and are totally rude and ignorant or entitled.

job_title: Operations Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Always working as a team with catering, ITS, and coworkers.  Team shares responsibilities and learns a large amount about hospitality throughout working here.
cons: If a coworker calls in sick, responsibilities are put on the other workers during that shift, making the work time possibly more stressful, depending on the amount of events.

job_title: Community Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Working for SHaRE was a great experience because I had many easygoing interactions with student residents, the workload was very doable, scheduling was flexible, and there was a $0.50/hr increase after working for a year and a positive evaluation.
cons: Upper management didn’t really back up student employee safety concerns about Public Safety refusing to escort us to our cars after NOC shifts.

review_title: Great Summer Position for Professional Growth
job_title: Facilities Team Leader in San Francisco, CA
pros: Flexible schedule, well paid, great compensation, good training, great location, and great housing. The people you meet are incredible and there is plenty of opportunity for growth, recognition and fun.
cons: Working with students, some incompetence by the staff and supervisors. Departments are not always willing to help one another. Lack of communication.

review_title: One gear in an adjunct machine.
job_title: Lecturer in San Francisco, CA
pros: Many of the students were engaged and fun to work with. Benefits package for part-time employees was a nice (rare) touch, though I didn't need it at the time. Decent salary.
cons: Treated as an expendable, replaceable adjuncter by the department I taught for. Many (half?) of the students didn't have a strong enough grasp of English to benefit from the course.

review_title: Finance Tutor for the Learning and Writing Center
job_title: Finance Tutor in San Francisco, CA
pros: flexibility in terms of scheduling. There is no set schedule for tutoring, it's based on weekly availability updates and getting contacted by individual students.
cons: Nothing to complain about. You can work directly with teachers about the studied topics in class, therefore you can get prepared before a tutoring meeting.

job_title: Manager, Operations in San Francisco, CA
pros: This is cheesey but true: USF is family to me. My supervisors are incredibly inspiring women who lead through positive reinforcement. They know my strengths and care about my well-being and everyone here is extremely welcoming and passionate about helping other colleagues and our students. I've worked here for a year and I'm so happy. My superiors are open to my ideas and I am able to build my own projects.
cons: Office politics and bureaucracy like any university.

review_title: Positive experience as a working student
job_title: Student Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: flexible work schedule for a student; interaction with other students and with professors; lots of free time to work on homework
cons: no room for advancement besides small increase in pay and title (level I, II, III, etc) each semester/year; can change relationship with professors if you work in the same department you study in

job_title: Laboratory Instructor in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Excellent way for graduate students to teaching experience and make a little extra money on the side. 
Course director's are committed to both lab instructors and students and in my experience have been fairly flexible about missing meetings and class on occasions for conflicts such as scientific meetings, intensive experiments, etc.
cons: Time commitment can be up to 20 hours a week, particularly if you haven't taught a class before.  Pay not great for this amount of work.

job_title: French TA and BUS 100 Mentor in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Student jobs were a great way to get to know people on campus (both faculty and other students) and get involved in meaningful projects. I was a language tutor for French and mentoring freshman students and loved both jobs.
Working on campus is also a good way for international students to make a little extra cash.
cons:
Teaching French required a lot of unpaid extra work to prepare lessons and grade students. 
We are paid minimum wage

job_title: Ambassador in San Francisco, CA

cons: Management can be a bit disorganized at times- USF is going through some changes and it's unclear who will still be around after the changes take effect.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Always learning something new and it is never boring! Things are always changing so you need to know how to roll with the punches.
cons: You will work a lot. This is not a job for the weak of heart or those looking for a place to hide and make money.

job_title: Student Assistant in San Francisco, CA

cons: Many departments are unorganized and communication between departments is even worse. In terms of culture, this is a rich kid school so many students feel entitled which is hard to deal with in a work environment.

review_title: Very Amazing Experience from a Student Employee
job_title: Student Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Make Your Own schedule based on your classes, Very good pay rates, Very friendly co-workers

job_title: Student Assistant in San Francisco, CA

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA

job_title: Student Assistant in San Francisco, CA

review_title: Student Assistant in the Marketing Communications Department

job_title: Resident Director in San Francisco, CA

review_title: Great academic, not so good IT
job_title: in San Francisco, CA

job_title: Teaching Assistant in San Francisco, CA
